"But we must also acknowledge that poverty is sticky and despair, dogged. The legacy effects of American oppression — which destroyed families, ingrained cultural violence, and denied generations of African-Americans the luxury of accruing and transferring intergenerational wealth — cannot simply be written off."

I agree. Racism, America's Original Sin, is never far below the surface in too many individuals. However, on an institutional level, I believe it's closely tied to class warfare. Since the conservative movement's attack on the New Deal gathered steam three decades ago the super-rich have been seizing back what they believe is rightfully theirs at the expense of people who used to work for a decent living. Capital-friendly trade and tax policies drained the heart and tax-base from communities as factories closed, jobs were exported or eliminated and families stripped of their livelihoods. This is the modern-day oppression, and it is really what's behind the Detroit bankruptcy. Meanwhile, Big Capital's political servants and their mouthpieces like Hannity and Limbaugh fan the flames of racism to pit working people (actual or would-be) against each other.

I like your solution focused vision for Detroit instead of the Republican slash and burn hedge fund mentality of fixing and turning around failed companies and communities. I could cut pensions. I could bulldoze neighborhoods. Can"t we create something that works here? What is America about? Go out and put America's best urban planners to work?

I just feel so weary of the typical Republican playbook funded by the Koch brothers, ALEC, and the Heritage Foundation.

They are interesting ideas but I am not so convinced that artificially increasing population is the solution if there is no twentieth first century jobs for these people. Given that we cannot morally reduce obligations like pensions too much, the only thing that the city can reduce is service cost. The best way to reduce service cost is to increase population density and that means downsizing Detroit.  What about subsidized land/home/apartment swaps such that people will voluntarily live in closer proximity? From the revenue side, Detroit needs a pro-growth strategy. May be that it is possible to grow given the much lower standard of living and labor cost that comes with this local depression. The trick is to educate the population to take advantage of it. I know that both my ideas and Winning Progressive's ideas sound crazy but Detroit cannot be turn around without out-of-the-box ideas. There is clearly no easy solution but clearly plenty of hard work.

Detroit's $18 billion in debt represents the spending and future liabilities that we incurred in 18 days of war in Iraq and Afghanistan. Obviously it will take more than that amount to get Detroit back on its feet, but it is important to keep in the mind that we have the financial wherewithal to reinvigorate Detroit if we really want to.

Another key to reinvigorating Detroit is to restore some population density, and the economic activity that goes with it. One way to do so is to make Detroit a safe haven for undocumented immigrants. Let undocumented immigrants who do not have criminal records and are already in the U.S. be free of fear of deportation if they move to Detroit. And for people who want to immigrate to the U.S., create an expedited system that ensures quick approval for any law-abiding immigrant who agrees to live in Detroit for at least five years.

A second way to increase density is urban homesteading. The city government in Detroit has taken possession of tens of thousands of vacant lots and thousands of other lots in the city have long been abandoned. Why not enact an Urban Homestead Act, that combines free land with a $100,000 grant to build or restore a house on that land to any law-abiding citizen who agrees to live there for at least five years?

Far from being a Clinton-hater, I ackowledge him to be our last unambiguously successful president. He served two terms and accomplished much, and did much of that while working effectively (after severe settling trials) with a a fundamentally opposed Republican House. Dubya's place in history, to be accurate, will need a lot more time and distance to determine, but it consisted of at least some good things and more than a few bad things, and he served two terms, as well. Mr. Obama will serve two terms and, thus far, under circumstances similar to Clinton's, has failed to tame an opposed House by refusing to really work with them, actually creating that vitriolically opposed House majority with ObamaCare, and squandering great opportunities our first black president had: our politics are frozen, and great questions remain unanswered because of the lack of skills at forging consensus and compromise that Clinton so abundantly and manifestly possessed.

But if you're going to poke fun at a president for his sexual foibles, although those officially parsed back then don't compare to Filner's (although the Billster was accused credibly of both extreme crudeness with women and actual rape), Clinton certainly presents himself as an immense target.

Now, this was a serious response, demonstrating that in a response to a response to a Gail Collins comment, I feel no particular compulsion to write humorously.

Janet:

Sorry you feel that way. But my writing humorously in response to Gail's columns, as I have regularly, twice per week for many years when she's in town and not on vaca or touting a book (and having been awarded many "picks" for those efforts), remains pretty well read and liked, if not "thumbed", consistent with the practice developed by many Times readers of comments who have adopted this practice as the latest form of "Volvo bashing".

Perhaps late next Wednesday night, when reading her Thursday op-ed, I should start placing at the beginning of my responses the cautionary:

"Warning: this comment is intended only for people blessed with a sense of humor who wish to be entertained while trying to figure out the point intended. All others, please refer to Winning Pogressive's comment (yes, Janet, that means you)."

Not fair. I insist on responding to a Collins piece with humor; yet the subject you treat with today hasn't really been funny since Frank and Dean were cutting things up on the stage of the Sands. Remember those days? When the complementary roles of men and women were so massively accepted? Men made the money, women made the men.

Of course, I could trot out my Billster advice about Filner.

Filner needs to go; but, then, I thought the same thing in 1998-1999, when William Jefferson Blythe III (Bill Clinton to most), was found to have engaged in interesting behavior, in the Oval Office no less, with Monica Lewinsky, a White House intern (female), prevailed upon to read poetry to him and perform other acts that Americans quickly had to learn how to define, kinda-sorta, to their children, to their everlasting and fancy-dancing embarrassment.

He was impeached over it, though the given reason was lying about it and other things (imagine that), but wasn't Senate-convicted. He made the Hillster as people lionized her stoic internalization of hubby's wanderings. He should have gone after he won, but didn't; and sort of dribbled for two years until Dubya and Darth Vader came along to eventually serve as the reason for all Barack Obama's troubles. But he really became a joke.

People should shame Filner into resigning, as essentially a loser. What Clinton's impeachment really proved is that messing around doesn't brand you a loser: what brands you a loser is getting CAUGHT.

While I certainly feel badly for the remaining residents of Detroit, I think it's wrong to say they did not ask for this.

In this country we cannot blame "the government" for anything. We the people are the government. Detroit's government, and the poor decisions it made, are the results of voters' continuing willingness to look the other way (or worse yet, be willing enablers) as their elected "leaders" dug an ever-deepening hole.

Everything our governments (fed and state) do can and should be blamed on the citizens who put the elected officials in office. If we don't like what they are doing then we should get rid of them, otherwise when the things get ugly we should blame ourselves.

JPG,

The difference is that none of the voters in the northeast kept voting for Sandy to "visit" them repeatedly over the last 30 years!

Likening the Retirees of Detroit to the Citizens of areas impacted by Hurricane Sandy is a good analogy for me. Neither group "asked for" the travails that have come their way, nor did they have any real way of protecting their assets once trouble appeared on the horizon.

The pensions of the municipal employees of Detroit need to be adequately funded and they need to be funded promptly. Parts of the bankruptcy proceedings will undoubtedly drag on for years; pension relief absolutely needs to be on a much faster track.

We also need to fess up to the fact that Detroit is not the only Municipality with inadequate resources to meet the pensions promised to employees. Perhaps our Senators and Representatives could actually do something useful for our Citizens and come up with rules, regulations & either loans or straight-out funding to address this impending crisis.

Having governmental agencies promise pensions to their employees and then suddenly discover that the cupboards are bare absolutely cannot be allowed to stand.

How about an aggressive 5-year program to get all pension funds onto a sound footing?

Most physicians don't ask their patients about their mental health even when they are suffering from diseases such as diabetes and heart disease that have high rates of comorbidity with mental illnesses. This is due to a combination of not being certain what to do if the patient reports such a problem and also because of the profit motive of not wanting to spend time for which physicians aren't going to get reimbursed. Unless there is some obvious sign of neglect of the child due to the mother's mental illness it is unlikely pediatricians will ask about PPD.
By the way, it is interesting the writer could write a whole column about a major mental health problem without once mentioning psychiatry (other than in the title of a journal). As many patients who suffer from PPD require treatment with an antidepressant that neither social workers or psychologists can prescribe, it might be worth considering that psychiatrists might have a major role.

I am old enough to remember a time when politicians got away with aggressive, boorish behavior and it didn't make headlines. From the tidbits I've heard about president Lyndon Johnson, he would likely be placed under indictment if he were around these days and plying his grabby ways. In the early days of NPR, one of my fellow reporters, a woman, said there was a senator who would place his hands on the inside of her leg and escalate upward with every question of an interview. One such was from Texas, she said.

Politics and government do not make up the epicenter of what, in polite circles, is considered out of bounds and unusual behavior in the sexual realm. Indeed, when I have traveled around the country and heard various stories of rampant goings on in out of the way places, Washington seems tame in comparison. In DC, people have to be concerned about re-election or stories making the media, but in the hinterlands there is little such danger. The nation's capital, and New York right now, seem so bad because we hear about their transgressions; those of our neighbors, friends or relatives? Not as much.

Our surprise, I think, about the actions of mayors and others is that we assume that, at this stage and with those responsibilities, people should have learned how to behave or at least curb themselves until they get home. Yet, we will never tame the human beast.
